overview_of_class:
The focus of the course is the creation of new performances that adapt fiction and film from the American 1950s. The course examines the "paranoia" theme in postwar American popular culture, as expressed in selected American stories and short novels (as well as some poetry and nonfiction) written between 1945 and 1963. A required screening and discussion, from 2 to 5 on most Fridays, relates a film (either a Hollywood feature or a documentary) to the week's reading.

THEATRE CREDIT. This course satisfies one unit of the "History, Literature, and Criticism" requirement in the Theatre Department.

ENROLLMENT. Approx. 10. E-mail request for permission directly to instructor, during SoC pre-registration, at: edwdoyle@northwestern.edu or edwdoyle1@gmail.com.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Contract grading, outcome-based evaluation. Two small-group performances. Short written responses to readings and in-class performance work. Attendance is mandatory.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
REQUIRED READING
? Stories by James Baldwin and John Cheever.
? Short novels by Shirley Jackson, Gwendolyn Brooks, Sylvia Plath, and John Barth.
? Selections from Naked Lunch by William S. Burroughs.
? "Electronic reserve room" copies of all readings available on Canvas.

REQUIRED VIEWING.
Scenes from Invaders from Mars (1953).
Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1956).
Scenes from Salt of the Earth (1953).
The Atomic Cafe (1982).
Sunset Boulevard (1950).
A Raisin in the Sun (1961).
The World, the Flesh, and the Devil (1959).
Rear Window (1954).
The Manchurian Candidate (1962).
